Capital factors are provided for a variety of standardized product forms for guaranteed minimum death and maturity benefits commonly offered for segregated fund guarantee products in Canada and the United States. Below is a general description of the product forms modelled. More details can be found in Table 5 of section 8.5.

\r\n

Guaranteed Minimum Death Benefit (GMDB) forms modelled include the following:

\r\n
    \r\n
  1. \r\n

    Return of Premium (ROP): provides a death benefit guarantee equal to the higher of the\r\n account value or the premiums paid.

    \r\n
    2. \r\n
  2. \r\n

    5% Annual Roll-up (ROLL): provides a guaranteed benefit that increases 5% per annum\r\n compounded at each contract anniversary with the guarantee frozen at age 80.

    \r\n
    3. \r\n
  3. \r\n

    Maximum Anniversary Value/Annual Ratchet (MAV): automatic annual reset of\r\n guarantee at each contract anniversary with resets frozen at age 80.

    \r\n
    4. \r\n
  4. \r\n

    10-year Rollover Contract (GMDB_10): guarantee can reset and term-to-maturity also\r\n will reset to 10 years. No resets are permitted in the final 10 years prior to contract\r\n maturity.

    \r\n
    5. \r\n
\r\n

Guaranteed Minimum Maturity Benefits (GMMB) forms modelled include:

\r\n
    \r\n
  1. \r\n

    Fixed Maturity Date (FIXED): guarantee is level and applies up to the fixed maturity\r\n date.

    \r\n
    2. \r\n
  2. \r\n

    10-year Rollover Maturity Benefit (GMMB_10): guarantee can be reset and term-tomaturity\r\n also resets to 10 years. No resets are permitted in the 10 years prior to contract\r\n maturity.

    \r\n
    3. \r\n
  3. \r\n

    Guaranteed Minimum Surrender Benefit After 10 Years (GMSB_10): guarantee comes\r\n into effect 10 years after contract issue. If the guaranteed value at 10 years is greater than\r\n the account value at surrender, a "top-up" benefit equal to the difference is paid.

    \r\n
    4. \r\n
\r\n

8.2. Documentation and reporting

\r\n

Given the complexity of this calculation, for auditing purposes the Appointed Actuary is required to keep supporting schedules of all the calculations for each step building up to the final numbers detailed in the MCCSR form. Also, the Appointed Actuary is required to detail the calculation in the segregated fund section of the Appointed Actuary's Report. Forms 90.010 and 90.015 must be completed.

\r\n

The columns of the reporting form on page 90.010 are filled in as follows:

\r\n
\r\n
Column 01 - Guaranteed Value
\r\n
\r\n

This is the amount guaranteed in all segregated funds. If the funds are subject to guarantees of differing amounts, for example 100% on death and 75% on maturity, report the larger amount here.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 02 - Market Value
\r\n
\r\n

This is the market value of all segregated funds.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 03 - Total Gross Calculated Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

This is the total gross calculated requirement for all segregated funds.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 04 - Credit for Reinsurance Ceded
\r\n
\r\n

Report credit for amounts ceded in column 04. Note that amounts ceded under arrangements deemed to constitute unregistered reinsurance (reference section 10.2) must be deducted from Available Capital/Margin on page 20.030, line 085 of the OSFI 87 form by Canadian companies, and on page 13.000, line 340 of the OSFI 86 form by foreign branches. Deposits held for unregistered reinsurance, for a period not less than the remaining guarantee term, in excess of policy liabilities and any required margins (see section 10.6) can be used to reduce the net required segregated fund risk component on the reinsured policies to a minimum of zero.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 05 - Net Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

This is determined as:

\r\n

(Total Gross Calculated Requirements \xe2\x88\x92 Credit for Reinsurance Ceded)

\r\n
\r\n
Column 06 \xe2\x80\x93 Credit for OSFI-Approved Hedging Programs
\r\n
\r\n

This is the dollar equivalent of the maximum allowable reduction. It is determined as:

\r\n

(Maximum allowable percentage reduction \xc3\x97 Net Requirements)

\r\n

where the maximum percentage reduction is the reduction that was determined at the time of approval. See the OSFI Advisory: Recognition of Hedge Contracts in the Determination of the Segregated Fund Guarantee Capital Requirement for Life Insurance Companies dated December 2008 .

\r\n

This column may also be used to enter the amount of a negative Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal Benefit Hedging Liability (enter the amount as a positive value in this column) to effectively floor this negative value at zero in determining the Net Required Component in Column 8.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 07 - Net Actuarial Liabilities Held
\r\n
\r\n

This is the total net actuarial liability held on the balance sheet for segregated fund guarantee risks., excluding deferred income taxesFootnote 105.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 08 - Net Required Component
\r\n
\r\n

This is determined as:

\r\n

(Net Requirements (column 5) \xe2\x88\x92 Credit for OSFI-Approved Hedging Programs \xe2\x88\x92 Net Actuarial Liabilities Held)

\r\n

Line 099 must not be less than zero in total.

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

The columns of the reporting form on page 90.015 are filled in as follows:

\r\n
\r\n
Column 01 - Factor Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

This is the gross calculated requirement based on the OSFI-approved factors.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 02 - OSFI Approved Internal Model Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

For OSFI-approved models, this is the gross calculated requirement based on company-specific internal models.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 03 - Total Gross Calculated Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

For OSFI-approved models, transition rules apply:

\r\n

In the first year of approval, Total Gross Calculated Requirements = 50% of the Factor Requirements + 50% of the Internal Model Requirements.

\r\n

Thereafter, Total Gross Calculated Requirements = 100% of the Internal Model Requirements.

\r\n

Otherwise, Total Gross Calculated Requirements = 100% of the Factor Requirements.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 04 - Credit for Reinsurance Ceded
\r\n
\r\n

Report credit for amounts ceded in column 04. Note that policy liabilities ceded under arrangements deemed to constitute unregistered reinsurance (reference section 10.2) must be deducted from Available Capital/Margin on page 20.030, line 085 of the OSFI 87 form by Canadian companies, and on page 13.000, line 340 of the OSFI 86 form by foreign branches. Deposits held for unregistered reinsurance, for a period not less than the remaining guarantee term, in excess of policy liabilities and any required margins (see section 10.6) can be used to reduce the net required segregated fund risk component on the reinsured policies to a minimum of zero.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 05 - Net Requirements
\r\n
\r\n

This is determined as:

\r\n

(Total Gross Calculated Requirements \xe2\x88\x92 Credit for Reinsurance Ceded)

\r\n
\r\n
Column 06 - Credit for OSFI-Approved Hedging Programs
\r\n
\r\n

This is the dollar equivalent of the maximum allowable reduction. It is determined as:

\r\n

(Maximum allowable percentage reduction \xc3\x97 Net Requirements)

\r\n

where the maximum percentage reduction is the reduction that was determined at the time of approval. See the OSFI Advisory: Recognition of Hedge Contracts in the Determination of the Segregated Fund Guarantee Capital Requirement for Life Insurance Companies dated December 2008.

\r\n

This column may also be used to enter the amount of a negative Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal Benefit Hedging Liability (enter the amount as a positive value in this column) to effectively floor this negative value at zero in determining the Net Required Component in Column 8.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 07 - Net Actuarial Liabilities Held
\r\n
\r\n

This is the total net actuarial liability held on the balance sheet for segregated fund guarantee risks, excluding deferred income taxesFootnote 104.

\r\n
\r\n
Column 08 - Net Required Component
\r\n
\r\n

This is determined as:

\r\n

(Net Requirements (column 5) \xe2\x88\x92 Credit for OSFI Approved Hedging Programs \xe2\x88\x92 Net Actuarial Liabilities Held)

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

Note that the amount reported on page 90.010, column 08, line 230 should be the same as the amount reported on page 90.015, column 08, line 100.

\r\n

8.3. Total gross calculated requirement

\r\n

8.3.1. Overview

\r\n

It is expected that the MCCSR methodology for Total Gross Calculated Requirement ("TGCR") will be applied on a policy-by-policy basis (i.e., seriatim). If the company adopts a cell-based approach, only materially similar contracts should be grouped together. Specifically, all policies comprising a "cell" must display substantially similar characteristics for those attributes expected to affect risk-based capital (e.g., definition of guaranteed benefits, attained age, policy duration, years-to-maturity, market-to-guaranteed value, asset mix, etc.). The TGCR and Net Actuarial Liabilities Held for the purpose of determining capital requirements for segregated funds using prescribed or approved factors should not include deferred income taxes.

\r\n

The portfolio TGCR is the sum of the TGCR calculations for each policy or cell. The result for any given policy (cell) may be negative, zero or positive. In total, the TGCR cannot be negative.

\r\n

The TGCR for a given policy is equal to:\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n TGCR\r\n =\r\n GV\r\n \xc3\x97\r\n \r\n f\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \xe2\x88\x92\r\n AV\r\n \xc3\x97\r\n \r\n g\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n , where GV = current guaranteed minimum benefit, AV = current account balance,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n f\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n =\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n benefit cost factor,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n g\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n =\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n margin offset factor and\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n is a vector that defines the risk characteristics for the policy. The factors\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n f\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n and\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n g\r\n ^\r\n \r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n are described more fully in section 8.7.1. The TGCR is calculated separately for each guaranteed minimum benefit (i.e., death, maturity and surrender).

\r\n

The model assumptions for the TGCR Factors are documented in section 8.3.2.

\r\n

There are four (4) major steps in determining the TGCR for a given policy/cell:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Classify the asset exposure (section 8.4);
    • \r\n
  • Determine the risk attributes (section 8.5);
    • \r\n
  • Retrieve the appropriate nodes (section 8.6);
    • \r\n
  • Use the supplied functions to determine the requirement (section 8.7).
    • \r\n
\r\n

The first step requires the company to categorize the asset value for the given policy/cell by mapping the entire exposure to one of the prescribed "fund classes" as described in section 8.4. TGCR factors are provided for each asset class.

\r\n

The second step requires the company to determine (or derive) the appropriate attributes for the given policy or cell. The attributes needed to access the factor tables and calculate the required values are:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • \r\n

    Product form ("Guarantee Definition"), P.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Guarantee level, G.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Adjustment to guaranteed value upon partial withdrawal ("GMDB/GMMB Adjustment"), A.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Fund class, F.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Attained age of the policyholder, X, (for GMDB only, use a 4-year setback for female lives).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Contract maturity age, M, (for GMDB only, use a 4-year setback for female lives).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Time-to-next maturity date, T.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Ratio of account value to guaranteed value, \xcf\x86.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Total "equivalent" account-based charges, MER ("management expense ratio").

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Reset utilization rate, R (where applicable).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    In-the-money termination rate, S (guaranteed surrender benefits only).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
\r\n

Other required policy values include:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • \r\n

    Total account value on which the guaranteed benefit is calculated, AV.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Current GMDB, GMMB and/or GMSB.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Total net spread available to fund guaranteed benefits ("margin offset"), \xce\xb1.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
\r\n

The next steps \xe2\x80\x93 retrieving the appropriate nodes and using the supplied functions to determine the requirement \xe2\x80\x93 are explained in sections 8.6 and 8.7. Software tools have been developed to assist companies in these efforts. If an insurer is unable to use the supplied tools, it will be required to develop software of its own. In such a situation, the insurer should contact OSFI for specific guidance on how to develop its own lookup and extraction routines. A calculation example demonstrating the application of the various component factors to a sample policy is provided in section 8.7.3.

\r\n

In this chapter, GMDB, GMMB, GMSB are generically denoted by GV. AV generically denotes either Account Value or Market Value. The total "equivalent" account charges should include all amounts assessed against policyholder accounts, expressed as a level spread per year (in basis points). This quantity is called the Management Expense Ratio ("MER") and is defined as the average amount (in dollars) charged against policyholder funds in a given year divided by average account value. Normally, the MER would vary by fund class and be the sum of investment management fees, mortality & expense charges, guarantee fees/risk premiums, etc. The total spread available to fund the guaranteed benefits (i.e., GMDB, GMMB, GMSB costs) is called the "margin offset" (denoted by \xce\xb1) and should be net of spread-based costs and expenses (e.g., net of maintenance expenses, investment management fees, trailer commissions, amounts required to provide for amortization of deferred acquisition costs, etc.). Section 8.8 describes how to determine MER and \xce\xb1 .

\r\n

The GMDB/GMMB/GMSB definition for a given policy/cell may not exactly correspond to those provided. In some cases, it may be reasonable to use the factors/formulas for a different product form. In other cases, the company might determine the TGCR based on two different guarantee definitions and interpolate the results to obtain an appropriate value for the given policy/cell. However, if the policy form is sufficiently different from those provided and there is no practical or obvious way to obtain a reasonable result, the insurer should follow the instructions outlined in section 8.10.

\r\n

The general form of the TGCR may be written as:

\r\n
\r\n

where:

\r\n
\r\n
GV
\r\n
\r\n

= current guaranteed minimum benefit (dollars)

\r\n
\r\n
AV
\r\n
\r\n

= current account value (dollars)

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n f\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n =\r\n f\r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
\r\n
\r\n

= cost factor per $1 of GV

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n g\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n =\r\n g\r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
\r\n
\r\n

= margin offset factor per $1 of AV (assuming 100 bps of available spread)

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n h\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n =\r\n h\r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
\r\n
\r\n

= asset mix diversification factor

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n i\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n =\r\n i\r\n (\r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
\r\n
\r\n

= time diversification factor

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

Under this notation,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n is used to generically represent the risk attribute set (e.g., product form, guaranteed level, asset class, attained age, etc.) for the policy, or some relevant subset thereof. \xce\xb1 is the company-determined net spread ("margin offset", in basis points per annum) available to fund the guaranteed benefits.

\r\n

Where more than one feature (i.e., guaranteed benefit) is present in a product, unless the company has a justifiable alternative for allocating the total available spread between the benefit types (e.g., explicitly defined risk charges), the split should be based on the proportionate gross guaranteed benefit costs. An example is provided in section 8.7.3 to illustrate this concept.

\r\n

In practice,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n f\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n ,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n g\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n ,\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n h\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n and\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n w\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n are values interpolated from the factor grid. The use of the factor grid is discussed more fully in section 8.7. The factor grid is a large pre-computed table developed using stochastic modeling for a wide array of combinations of the risk attribute set. The risk attribute set is defined by those policy/product characteristics that affect the risk profile (exposure) of the business: product form (guarantee definition), fund class, attained age, AV/GV ratio, time-to-maturity, etc.

\r\n

8.3.2. Assumptions for TGCR methodology published factors

\r\n

Each node in the factor grid is effectively the modeled result for a given "cell" assuming a $100 single deposit.

\r\n
Table 1: Model Assumptions & Product Characteristics
\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Account Charges (MER) Vary by fund class. See Table 2 later in this section.
Base Margin Offset 100 basis points per annum.
GMDB Description
    \r\n
  • ROP = return of premium.
    • \r\n
  • ROLL = 5% compound roll-up, frozen at age 80.
    • \r\n
  • MAV = annual ratchet (maximum anniversary value), frozen at age 80.
    • \r\n
  • GMDB_10 = 10-year rollover contract.
    • \r\n
GMMB & GMSB Descriptions
    \r\n
  • FIXED = fixed maturity date.
    • \r\n
  • GMSB_10 = 10-year guaranteed surrender benefit.
    • \r\n
  • GMMB_10 = 10-year rollover maturity benefit.
    • \r\n
GV Adjustment on Withdrawal "Pro-Rata by Market Value" and "Dollar-for-Dollar" are tested separately.
Surrender Charges Ignored (i.e., zero).
Base Policy Lapse Rate 6% p.a. at all policy durations. See also "Dynamic Lapse Multiplier".
Partial Withdrawals Flat 4% p.a. at all policy durations (as a % of AV). No dynamics.
Rollover (Renewal) Rate 85% at the end of each 10-year term (GMDB_10 and GMMB_10 only).
Dynamic Lapse Multiplier

Actual lapse rate = \xce\xbb \xc3\x97 [ Base Policy Lapse Rate ], where:

\r\n \r\n

\xce\xbb+= 1.6667, \xce\xbb-= 0.3333, a = \xe2\x80\x930.0952, b = 0.8010, c = 0.6279, d = 0.0654, h = 10 and T = time-to-next maturity.

Mortality 100% of CIA 1986\xe2\x80\x9392 ALB Male Aggregate Ultimate.
Fixed Expenses, Annual Fees Ignored (i.e., zero).
Discount Rate 5.5% annual effective (non-dynamic).
Elective Reset of GV Whenever the AV/GV ratio exceeds 115% (maximum 2 resets per year). No resets are permitted in the 10 years prior to the final "contract" maturity date.
In-The-Money Surrender (GMSB_10 only) Whenever the benefit is payable (i.e., 10 years after issue or last reset) and the AV/GV ratio is less 85%.
\r\n
Notes on Factor Development:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • \r\n

    The GMDB roll-up is compounded (not simple interest, not stepped at each anniversary) and is applied to the previous roll-up guaranteed value.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    The "Base Policy Lapse Rate" is the rate of policy termination (surrenders). Policy terminations (surrenders) are assumed to occur throughout the policy year (not only on anniversaries).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Partial withdrawals are assumed to occur at the end of each time period (quarterly).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    Account charges ("MER") represent the total amount (annualized, in basis points) assessed against policyholder funds (e.g., sum of investment management fees, mortality and expense charges, risk premiums, policy/administrative fees, etc.). They are assumed to occur throughout the policy year (not only on anniversaries).

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    For the GMDB_10 and GMMB_10 products, the contract rolls over (renews) at the end of each 10-year term for another 10 years. The guaranteed benefit resets to Z% of MV (after payment of any top-up maturity benefit for in-the-money maturity guarantees) where Z is typically 75 or 100.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    The guaranteed minimum surrender benefit (GMSB_10) comes into effect 10 years after contract issue. If the guaranteed value at 10 years is greater than the account value at surrender, a "top-up" benefit equal to the difference is paid.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
\r\n
Table 2: Account-Based Fund Charges (bps per annum)
\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Asset Class / Fund Account Value Charges (MER)
Money Market 110
Fixed Income (Bond) 200
Balanced 250
Low Volatility Equity 265
Diversified Equity 265
Intermediate Risk Equity 280
Aggressive or Exotic Equity 295
\r\n

The annualized total fund depletion rates (i.e., including the fixed 4% per annum partial withdrawal) are illustrated in Figure 1 for various AV/GV ratios and times to maturity.

\r\n
Figure 1: Fund Depletion Rates (Lapse + Partial Withdrawal) by AV/GV Ratio & Time-to-Maturity
\r\n
\r\n

8.4. Classifying the asset exposure

\r\n

8.4.1. Definition of asset classes

\r\n

The following criteria should be used to select the appropriate factors, parameters and formulas for the exposure represented by a specified guaranteed benefit. When available, the volatility of the long-term annualized total return for the fund(s) \xe2\x80\x93 or an appropriate benchmark \xe2\x80\x93 should conform to the limits presented. For this purpose, "long-term" is defined as twice the average projection period that would be applied to test the product in a stochastic model (generally, at least 25 years).

\r\n

Where data for the fund or benchmark are too sparse or unreliable, the fund exposure should be\r\n moved to the next higher volatility class than otherwise indicated. In reviewing the asset\r\n classifications, care should be taken to reflect any additional volatility of returns added by the\r\n presence of currency risk, liquidity (bid-ask) effects, short selling and speculative positions.

\r\n

All exposures/funds must be categorized into one of the following seven (7) asset classes:

\r\n
    \r\n
  1. Money Market/Short-Term
    2. \r\n
  2. Fixed Income
    3. \r\n
  3. Balanced
    4. \r\n
  4. Low Volatility Equity
    5. \r\n
  5. Broad-Based Diversified Equity
    6. \r\n
  6. Intermediate Risk Equity
    7. \r\n
  7. Aggressive or Exotic Equity
    8. \r\n
\r\n
\r\n
Money Market/Short-Term.
\r\n
\r\n

The fund is invested in money market instruments with an average remaining term-to-maturity of less than 365 days.

\r\n
\r\n
Fixed Income.
\r\n
\r\n

The fund is invested primarily in investment grade fixed income securities. Up to 25% of the fund within this class may be invested in diversified equities or high-yield bonds. The expected volatility of the fund returns will be lower than the Balanced fund class.

\r\n
\r\n
Balanced.
\r\n
\r\n

This class is a combination of fixed income securities with a larger equity component. The fixed income component should exceed 25% of the portfolio. Additionally, any aggressive or 'specialized' equity component should not exceed one-third (33.3%) of the total equities held. Should the fund violate either of these constraints, it should be categorized as an equity fund. These funds usually have a long-term volatility in the range of 8% \xe2\x88\x92 13%.

\r\n
\r\n
Low Volatility Equity.
\r\n
\r\n

This fund is comparable to the Broad-Based Diversified Equity class with the additional attributes noted below. Only funds that otherwise would be classified as Broad-Based Diversified Equity are candidates for this fund classification. For foreign funds, volatility should take into account the impact of currency fluctuations.

\r\n

The expected volatility of the fund should be less than 15.5% (annualized) and the aggressive/exotic equity component of the equity holdings should be less than 33.3% of the total equities by market value. Further, the overall asset holdings should satisfy at least one of the following conditions:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • \r\n

    The fund permanently maintains a relatively large cash or fixed income position (greater than 10% of the market value of assets) as part of its investment strategy;

    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • \r\n

    The fund is "income" oriented and contains a significant (greater than 10% of the market value of assets) proportion of stocks paying material and regular dividends that are automatically reinvested in the fund.

    \r\n
    • \r\n
\r\n
\r\n
Broad-Based Diversified Equity.
\r\n
\r\n

The fund is invested in a well-diversified mix of Canadian, U.S. or global equities. The foreign equity component must be comprised of liquid securities in well-developed markets. Funds in this category would exhibit long-term volatility comparable to that of the TSX. These funds should usually have a long-term volatility in the range of 13% \xe2\x88\x92 19%.

\r\n
\r\n
Intermediate Risk Equity.
\r\n
\r\n

The fund has a mix of characteristics from both the Diversified and Aggressive Equity Classes. These funds have a long-term volatility in the range of 19% \xe2\x88\x92 25%.

\r\n
\r\n
Aggressive or Exotic Equity.
\r\n
\r\n

This class comprises more volatile funds where risk can arise from: (a) underdeveloped markets, (b) uncertain markets, (c) high volatility of returns, (d) narrow focus (e.g., specific market sector), etc. The fund (or market benchmark) either does not have sufficient history to allow for the calculation of a long-term expected volatility, or the volatility is very high. This class would be used whenever the long-term expected annualized volatility is indeterminable or exceeds 25%.

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

8.4.2. Selecting appropriate investment classes

\r\n

The selection of an appropriate investment type should be done at the level for which the guarantee applies. For guarantees applying on a deposit-by-deposit basis, the fund selection is straightforward. However, where the guarantee applies across deposits or for an entire contract, the approach can be more complicated. In such instances, the approach is to identify for each policy where the "grouped holdings" fit within the categories listed and to classify the associated assets on this basis.

\r\n

A seriatim process is used to identify the "grouped" fund holdings, to assess the risk profile of the current fund holdings (possibly calculating the expected long-term volatility of the funds held with reference to the indicated market proxies), and to classify the entire 'asset exposure' into one of the specified choices. Here, 'asset exposure' refers to the underlying assets (segregated and/or general account investment options) on which the guarantee will be determined. For example, if the guarantee applies separately for each deposit year within the contract, then the classification process would be applied separately for the exposure of each deposit year.

\r\n

In summary, mapping the benefit exposure (i.e., the asset exposure that applies to the calculation of the guaranteed minimum benefits) to one of the prescribed asset classes is a multi-step process:

\r\n
    \r\n
  1. \r\n

    Map each separate and/or general account investment option to one of the prescribed asset classes. For some funds, this mapping will be obvious, but for others it will involve a review of the fund's investment policy, performance benchmarks, composition and expected long-term volatility.

    \r\n
    2. \r\n
  2. \r\n

    Combine the mapped exposure to determine the expected long-term volatility of current fund holdings. This will require a calculation based on the expected long-term volatilities for each fund and the correlations between the prescribed asset classes as given in Table 3.

    \r\n
    3. \r\n
  3. \r\n

    Evaluate the asset composition and expected volatility (as calculated in step 2) of current holdings to determine the single asset class that best represents the exposure, with due consideration to the constraints and guidelines presented earlier in this section.

    \r\n
    4. \r\n
\r\n

In step 1, the company should use the fund's actual experience (i.e., historical performance, inclusive of reinvestment) only as a guide in determining the expected long-term volatility. Due to limited data and changes in investment objectives, style and/or management (e.g., fund mergers, revised investment policy, different fund managers, etc.), the company may need to give more weight to the expected long-term volatility of the fund's benchmarks. In general, the company should exercise caution and not be overly optimistic in assuming that future returns will consistently be less volatile than the underlying markets.

\r\n

In step 2, the company should calculate the "volatility of current fund holdings" ( \xcf\x83 for the exposure being categorized) by the following formula using the volatilities and correlations in Table 3.

\r\n
\r\n

where

\r\n\r\n

is the relative value of fund i expressed as a proportion of total contract k value, \xcf\x81ij is the correlation between asset classes i and j and \xcf\x83i is the volatility of asset class i (see Table 3). An example is provided in Table 4.

\r\n
Table 3: Volatilities and Correlations for Prescribed Asset Classes
\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
ANNUAL\r\n VOLATILITY GENERAL\r\n ACCOUNT MONEY\r\n MARKET FIXED\r\n INCOME BALANCED LOW VOL\r\n EQUITY DIVERSE\r\n EQUITY INTERM\r\n EQUITY AGGR\r\n EQUITY
1% GENERAL\r\n ACCOUNT10.50 0.150 0 0 0 0
1% MONEY\r\n MARKET 0.50 10.20 0 0 0 0 0
6% FIXED\r\n INCOME 0.15 0.2010.50 0.25 0.25 0.20 0.10
11% BALANCED 0 0 0.50 10.80 0.95 0.75 0.65
15% LOW VOL\r\n EQUITY 0 0 0.25 0.8010.80 0.75 0.65
17% DIVERSE\r\n EQUITY 0 0 0.25 0.95 0.80 10.75 0.65
22% INTERM\r\n EQUITY 0 0 0.20 0.75 0.75 0.7510.70
26% AGGR\r\n EQUITY 0 0 0.10 0.65 0.65 0.65 0.701
\r\n

As an example, suppose three funds (Fixed Income, Diversified Equity and Aggressive Equity) are offered to clients on a product with a contract level guarantee (i.e., across all funds held within the policy). The current fund holdings (in dollars) for five sample contracts are shown in Table 4.

\r\n
Table 4: Fund Categorization Example
\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
1 2 3 4 5
MV Fund X (Fixed Income): 5,000 6,000 8,000 - 5,000
MV Fund Y (Diversified Equity): 9,000 5,000 2,000 5,000 -
MV Fund Z (Aggressive Equity): 1,000 4,000 - 5,000 5,000
Total Market Value: $15,000 $15,000 $10,000 $10,000 $10,000
Total Equity Market Value: $10,000 $9,000 $2,000 $10,000 $5,000
Fixed Income % (A): 33% 40% 80% 0% 50%
Fixed Income Test (A>75%): No No Yes No No
Aggressive % of Equity (B): 10% 44% n/a 50% 100%
Balanced Test (A>25% & B<33.3%): Yes No n/a No No
Volatility of Current Fund Holdings: 12.0% 12.1% 6.5% 19.6% 13.6%
Fund Classification: Balanced DiversifiedFootnote * Fixed Income Intermediate Diversified
\r\n

The "Volatility of Fund Holdings" for policy #1 is calculated as

\r\n
\r\n

Importantly, the volatility would be understated if we assumed zero correlation (e.g., all market returns are independent) since B contributes materially to the final value.

\r\n

8.5. Determining the risk attributes

\r\n

The \'Tabular\' approach for the TGCR component creates a multi-dimensional grid (array) by testing a very large number of combinations for the policy attributes. The results are expressed as factors. The TGCR is calculated by looking into (based on a "key") the large, pre-computed multi-dimensional tables and using multi-dimensional linear interpolation. The lookup "key" depends on the risk attributes for the policy\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xce\xb8\r\n \xcb\x9c\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n = (P, G, A, F , X , M ,T , \xcf\x86, \xce\x94, R, S ) where \xcf\x86 is the AV/GV ratio for the benefit exposure under consideration, \xce\x94 is the "MER Delta", R is the utilization rate of the elective reset option (if applicable) and S is the "in-the-money" termination rate on GMSB_10 policies. The "MER Delta" is calculated based on the difference between the actual MER and that assumed in the factor testing (see Table 2), subject to a cap (floor) of 100 bps (\xe2\x88\x92100 bps). See Table 5 for more details.

\r\n

For GMDB, there are 4 \xc3\x97 2 \xc3\x97 2 \xc3\x97 7 \xc3\x97 4 \xc3\x97 4 \xc3\x97 5 \xc3\x97 7 \xc3\x97 3 \xc3\x97 2 = 376,320 "nodes" in the "Basic Factor" grid. Interpolation will only be permitted across the six (6) dimensions: Contract Maturity Age (M), Attained Age (X), Time to Next Maturity (T), AV/GV Ratio (\xcf\x86), MER Delta (\xce\x94) and Reset Utilization Rate (R). The "In-the-Money" termination rate (S) is not used for GMDBs.

\r\n

For GMMB, there are 3 \xc3\x97 2 \xc3\x97 2 \xc3\x97 7 \xc3\x97 1 \xc3\x97 7 \xc3\x97 5 \xc3\x97 7 \xc3\x97 3 \xc3\x97 2 \xc3\x97 2 = 246,960 "nodes" in the "Basic Factor" grid. Interpolation will only be permitted across the six (6) dimensions: Contract Maturity Age (M), Time to Next Maturity (T), AV/GV Ratio (\xcf\x86), MER Delta (\xce\x94), Reset Utilization Rate (R) and In-the-Money Termination Rate (S). The "In-the-Money" termination rate (S) is only applies to the "GMSB_10" product form. The testing for guaranteed minimum maturity and surrender benefits assumed all lives were attained age 55 at the calculation date.

\r\n

Functions are available to assist the company in applying the TGCR Methodology. More fully described in section 8.7, these functions perform the necessary factor table lookups and associated multi-dimensional linear interpolations. If the insurer is unable to use the supplied functions, it will be required to develop its own. In such a case, the insurer should contact OSFI for specific details.

\r\n

The GMDB and GMMB/GMSB factors are respectively contained in the files "GMDBFactors_CTE95.csv" and "GMMBFactors_CTE95.csv". These are comma- separated value text files where each "row" represents the factors for a test policy as identified by its lookup key. Rows are terminated by new line and line feed characters. Factors are also provided at the CTE80 confidence level \xe2\x80\x93 the factor files are "GMDBFactors_CTE80.csv" and "GMMBFactors_CTE80.csv". For the determination of capital requirements, the "GMDBFactors_CTE95.csv" and "GMMBFactors_CTE95.csv" factors are to be used.

\r\n

Each row in the factor tables consists of three entries, described further below.

\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
1 2 3
Test Case Identifier (Key) Basic Cost or Diversification Factor Basic Margin Offset Factor or Zero (N/A)
\r\n

An individual test case (i.e., a node on the multi-dimensional matrix of factors) can be uniquely identified by its key, which is the concatenation of the relevant individual policy attribute keys (or some subset thereof) prefixed by a leading 'factor code'. The factor codes are shown below.

\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Factor Code Description
1 Basic GMDB "Cost" and "Margin Offset" factors.
2 Basic GMMB and GMSB "Cost" and "Margin Offset" factors.
3 Asset Mix Diversification factors for GMDB options.
4 Asset Mix Diversification factors for GMMB and GMSB options.
5 Time Diversification factors for GMDB options.
6 Time Diversification factors for GMMB and GMSB options.
\r\n
\r\n
Basic Cost Factor.
\r\n
\r\n

This is the term\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n f\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n in the formula for TGCR. The values in the factor grid represent CTE95 (or CTE80) of the sample distributionFootnote 106 for the present value of guaranteed minimum benefit cash flows (in excess of account value) in all future years (i.e., to the earlier of contract maturity and 30 years), normalized by current guaranteed value.Footnote 107 The policy attribute keys for the Cost factors are shown in Table 5.

\r\n
\r\n
Basic Margin Offset Factor.
\r\n
\r\n

This is the term\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n g\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n in the formula for TGCR. The values in the factor grid represent CTE95 (or CTE80) of the sample distribution for the present value of margin offset cash flows in all future years (i.e., to the earlier of contract maturity and 30 years), normalized by current account balance. The Basic Margin Offset Factors assume\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xce\xb1\r\n ^\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n = 100 basis points of "margin offset" (net spread available to fund the guaranteed benefits). The policy attribute keys for the Margin Offset factors are shown in Table 5.

\r\n
\r\n
Asset Mix Diversification Factor.
\r\n
\r\n

This is the term\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n h\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n in the formula for TGCR.\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n h\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n = h(P, G, R, S) is an adjustment factor that reflects the benefits of fund diversification (asset mix) at the company (i.e., total portfolio) level. Note that\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n h\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xe2\x89\xa4 1 depends on product form "P", guarantee level "G", reset utilization rate "R" (where applicable) and in-the-money termination rate "S" (GMSB only). The lookup keys for the Asset Mix Diversification factors are given in Table 6.

\r\n

DF should be set equal to 1 in the GetCost and GetTGCR functions (see section 8.7.1).

\r\n
\r\n
Time Diversification Factor.
\r\n
\r\n

This is the term\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n w\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n in the formula for TGCR.\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n w\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n = w(P, G, F , R, S) is an adjustment factor that attempts to capture the benefits (i.e., net reduction in guaranteed benefit costs) of a dispersed maturity profile. This adjustment applies on to maturity benefit factors only; it does not apply to death benefit factors. Note that\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n w\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \xe2\x89\xa4 1 also depends on fund class "F". If the company does not satisfy the time diversification criteria, then\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n w\r\n (\r\n \xe2\x88\x98\r\n )\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n = 1 (i.e., no time diversification benefit). Although the structure permits otherwise, the time diversification factors for GMDB are set to 1. The lookup keys for the Time Diversification factors are given in Table 7.

\r\n

This factor is set either to zero or one, based on the results of a time diversification test.

\r\n

To perform the test, the in-force maturity dates for each product/maturity guarantee form are grouped by "quarter-to-maturity" (i.e., 1, 2, \xe2\x80\xa6, N). For limited-term contracts that offer the client the opportunity to renew ("rollover"), the next maturity date should be used (not final contract maturity). Using current market value (at the calculation date), the current market value in each future 3-month time period is determined.

\r\n

If the current market value in any given quarter exceeds 10% of the total, then the portfolio fails the test. If the current market value in each quarter is less than or equal to 10% of the total, the portfolio passes the test. If the portfolio fails the test, DT is set equal to zero in the GetCost and GetTGCR functions (see section 8.7.1). Otherwise, DT is set equal to one.

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

Table 5: Grid of Cost and Margin Offset Factors

\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n

    \r\n

    • \r\n

    • \r\n
  • 2 : Not used.
    • \r\n
  • 3 : 10-year rollover.
    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : 75%
    • \r\n
  • 1 : 100%
    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : Pro-rata by market value.
    • \r\n
  • 1 : Dollar-for-dollar.
    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : Not used.
    • \r\n
  • 1 : Money Market.
    • \r\n

    \r\n

    • \r\n

    • \r\n

    \r\n

    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : 1 year
    • \r\n

    • \r\n
  • 2 : 5 years
    • \r\n
  • 3 : 8 years
    • \r\n
  • 4 : 10+ years
    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : 0.25
    • \r\n
  • 1 : 0.50
    • \r\n
  • 2 : 0.75
    • \r\n
  • 3 : 1.00
    • \r\n
  • 4 : 1.25
    • \r\n
  • 5 : 1.50
    • \r\n

    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : -100 bps
    • \r\n
  • 1 : 0 bps
    • \r\n

    • \r\n

    \r\n
  • 0 : 0%
    • \r\n

    • \r\n

    \r\n

\r\n

It is important to note that the lookup keys for the factor tables define certain values differently from the parameters (arguments) passed to the lookup/retrieval functions, as indicated in the following table. More details are provided in section 8.7.

\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Policy Attribute Key Interpretation Function Arguments
Contract Maturity Age, M. Years from Valuation Date. Equal to [Contract Maturity Age] less [Attained Age]. Actual contract maturity age.
AV/GV Ratio, \xcf\x86. Ratio of current Account Balance (AV) to Guaranteed Value (GV). AV and GV are provided separately.
MER Delta, \xce\x94. [Actual MER] less [Assumed MER], in basis points. The "Assumed MERs" are shown in Table 2. MER (annualized, in basis points p.a.) is passed directly.
\r\n

8.6. Retrieving the appropriate nodes

\r\n

Table 8 provides some sample lookup keys (assuming the annualized fund based charges equal the base assumption, hence \xce\x94 = 0), while Table 9 shows the "Basic Cost" and "Basic Margin Offset" values from the factor grid for some sample GMDB and GMMB policies. All sample policies in Table 9 use a 100% guarantee level, base MERs and no resets. As mentioned earlier, the Base Margin Offset factors (in the tables) assume 100 basis points of "available spread". The "Margin Offset Factors" are therefore scaled by the ratio \xce\xb1/100 , where \xce\xb1 = the actual margin offset (in basis points per annum) for the policy being valued. Hence, the margin factor for the 7th policy is exactly half the factor for node '11105214210' (the 4th sample policy in Table 9). That is, 0.02093 = 0.5 \xc3\x97 0.04187.

\r\n

Where more than one feature (i.e., guaranteed benefit) is present in a product, unless the company has a justifiable alternative for allocating the total available spread between the benefit types (e.g., explicitly defined risk charges), the split should be based on the proportionate gross guaranteed benefit costs. An example of this allocation is provided in section 8.7.3.

\r\n

Table 8: Sample Lookup Keys

\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
KEY NODE TYPE PRODUCT / GV% GV ADJUST FUND CLASS ATT.. AGE / MAT. AGE NEXT MAT. AV/GV RESET UTIL.% ITM TERM%
10103214110 A GMDB-ROP / 100% Pro-rata Balanced Allocation 65 / 80 10+ 50% 0% n/a
200150444110 A GMMB-Fixed / 75% $-for-$ Diverse Equity 55 / 75 5 125% 100% n/a
3311 B GMDB_10 / 100% n/a n/a n/a n/a n/a 100% n/a
43100 B GMMB_10 / 100% n/a n/a n/a n/a n/a 0% n/a
611411 C GMSB_10 / 100% n/a Low Vol. Equity n/a n/a n/a 100% 100%
\r\n

A = Basic Cost and Margin Offset Factors; B = Asset Mix Diversification Factors; C = Time Diversification Factors.

\r\n
